text: you'll find curries all over the West
Indies but this lamb version from
Jamaica is particularly rich and spicy
in the West Indies most curries would be
made with goat but goat can be hard to
find here
so lamb is a great substitute you want
to make sure that both the vegetables
and the lamb are really tender by the
end of this dish so I add the vegetables
about halfway through the cooking and
then they should finish at the same time
as the lamb you always want to season
your meat first before you do anything
else so I have my lamb stew meat and I'm
gonna just season it with some ginger
salt and curry powder and some black
pepper and then you could just let this
sit at room temperature while you make
the marinade if you look online at
recipes for West Indian curries you're
gonna see an ingredient called pimento
when I first saw it I was thinking do I
take the little thing out of the olive
but in fact it refers to allspice
berries it's just called pimento there
it's the exact same thing
after you put the marinade all over the
lamb you want to let it marinate for at
least two hours in the fridge or if you
have time you can do it overnight before
I brown the meat I am gonna just toast
the curry powder so I've used curry
powder twice I've used it in the
marinade and then I'm gonna use it also
toasted along with the meat so you want
to make sure not to overcrowd the pan
the lamb should have space around it so
that it can get nice and dark and brown
because in this dish that brown flavor
is just as important as the curry once
you've got all your meat nice and brown
you just back into the pan and just
enough water to cover you want to cook
this until the meat is practically
falling apart you really want it to be
nice and tender and imbued with the
flavors of the sauce when I had this
dish in Jamaica it was served with a
sweet mango chutney on the side which
was really nice with the meat but you
could also serve it with a really spicy
tart mango pickle if you want something
that's just a little bit brighter
Oh
Oh
